dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, Host_B, we're talking Bitcoin today, right? This thing is, like, fascinating because it's totally free from any central bank, no third-party audits needed.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Host B, we're talking Bitcoin today, right? This thing is, like, fascinating because it's totally free from any central bank, no third-party audits needed.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Bitcoin is a unique monetary asset in that it is free from the control of any central bank and doesnt need to be audited by a third party to ensure its value.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly! And what's wild is it’s all tracked by thousands of computers on this shared network, the blockchain, using cryptography. So much potential there, um, beyond just money.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly! And what's wild is it's all tracked by thousands of computers on this shared network, the blockchain, using cryptography. So much potential there, um, beyond just money.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is instead tracked and verified by thousands of computers on a shared network that is called a blockchain, which uses cryptography to reach consensus. Bitcoins underlying distributed ledger technology has the potential to not only dramatically overhaul finance, but also fields ranging from property ownership to health care and voting.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And you know, when it started back in 2009, hardly anyone even knew what it was. Satoshi Nakamoto, this mysterious developer.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And you know, when it started back in two thousand nine, hardly anyone even knew what it was. Satoshi Nakamoto, this mysterious developer.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As the decade began, only a handful knew anything about bitcoin, which was created on January 3, 2009 by a mysterious developer known to the world as Satoshi Nakamoto.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that name! And that little message he embedded in the very first block – a newspaper headline about banks needing a bailout after 2008. Talk about a statement.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that name! And that little message he embedded in the very first block - a newspaper headline about banks needing a bailout after two thousand eight. Talk about a statement.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Buried within the code of his Genesis block, Nakamoto embedded a reminder of what happens when too much trust is placed in banks. It was a headline from a British newspaper announcing the imminent bailout of the financial institutions following their collapse in 2008 and 2009: The Times 03/Jan/2009 Chancellor On Brink of Second Bailout for Banks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Like, a real dig at the traditional system. And for years, it was just this fringe thing for programmers and, uh, libertarian types.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Like, a real dig at the traditional system. And for years, it was just this fringe thing for programmers and, uh, libertarian types.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For the first five years or so, bitcoin largely went unnoticed, appealing to a fringe group of programmers and libertarian idealists.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I mean, those first 50 Bitcoins for mining a block were worth less than a penny, and now they're worth, like, hundreds of thousands of dollars. Wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I mean, those first fifty Bitcoins for mining a block were worth less than a penny, and now they're worth, like, hundreds of thousands of dollars. Wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The first full decade of digital currency without banks kicked off a year later, on January 1, 2010, with the mining of bitcoin block number 32620, which rewarded its miner with 50 bitcoin, then worth less than a single penny but now worth about $375,000.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Absolutely insane! But it hasn't all been smooth sailing, has it? We've had the scandals, like Silk Road...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely insane! But it hasn't all been smooth sailing, has it? We've had the scandals, like Silk Road...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The nascent technology has been plagued by infamous scandals like the FBIs shuttering of underground bitcoin-fueled drug and contraband marketplace Silk Road in 2013 and the $450 million hacking of cryptocurrency exchange Mt. Gox in 2014.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, definitely. And Mt. Gox, that huge hack. So many setbacks. And then the 2017 frenzy, with prices soaring and then, you know, a lot of people losing money on other tokens.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, definitely. And Mt. Gox, that huge hack. So many setbacks. And then the twenty seventeen frenzy, with prices soaring and then, you know, a lot of people losing money on other tokens.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The nascent technology has been plagued by infamous scandals like the FBIs shuttering of underground bitcoin-fueled drug and contraband marketplace Silk Road in 2013 and the $450 million hacking of cryptocurrency exchange Mt. Gox in 2014. At the end of 2017, the frenzy in cryptocurrency speculation peaked with bitcoin at $20,000 and produced thousands of worthless cryptocurrency tokens and investor losses in the billions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it was, uh, a rollercoaster. But the core believers, they haven't given up their vision for a decentralized economy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it was, uh, a rollercoaster. But the core believers, they haven't given up their vision for a decentralized economy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Bitcoin believers have not given up their idealistic visions for an economy outside the influence of central control.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, not at all! And here’s the kicker, the really ironic part: now you see big players like IBM, JPMorgan, even Cargill, they're all jumping on the blockchain bandwagon.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, not at all! And here's the kicker, the really ironic part: now you see big players like I B M, J P Morgan, even Cargill, they're all jumping on the blockchain bandwagon.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In fact in a bit cruel irony, some of the most enthusiastic supporters and co-opters of blockchain technology today are those same big companies, ranging from IBM and Cargill to JPMorgan, that early bitcoin believers were rallying against.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I know, right? The same companies that early Bitcoiners were, like, rallying against. It's a bit of a cruel irony.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, right? The same companies that early Bitcoiners were, like, rallying against. It's a bit of a cruel irony.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In fact in a bit cruel irony, some of the most enthusiastic supporters and co-opters of blockchain technology today are those same big companies, ranging from IBM and Cargill to JPMorgan, that early bitcoin believers were rallying against.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: A total flip! And can we just pause for a second and think about the guy who paid 10,000 Bitcoin for two pizzas back in 2010?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A total flip! And can we just pause for a second and think about the guy who paid ten thousand Bitcoin for two pizzas back in twenty ten?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: May 22, 2010 Programmer Laszlo Hanyecz buys two Papa Johns pizzas for $25 using 10,000 bitcoin, establishing its first market-based price: $0.0025

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh my gosh, the Papa John's pizza guy! [chuckles] That's, uh, that's gotta sting now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh my gosh, the Papa John's pizza guy! That's, uh, that's gotta sting now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Imagine that! So, looking ahead, it's not just about currency anymore, is it? It's property, healthcare, voting... the potential is enormous.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Imagine that! So, looking ahead, it's not just about currency anymore, is it? It's property, healthcare, voting... the potential is enormous.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Bitcoins underlying distributed ledger technology has the potential to not only dramatically overhaul finance, but also fields ranging from property ownership to health care and voting.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it feels like we're just scratching the surface of what this underlying technology, blockchain, can actually do.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it feels like we're just scratching the surface of what this underlying technology, blockchain, can actually do.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. It's gonna be interesting to watch these next few years unfold.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. It's gonna be interesting to watch these next few years unfold.
